comments.raw_text:
from Bug 654042 - bugzilla query advanced search selection boxes are too wide, and can be narrower so they all fit on one row

there are two rows 
1. Classification:  Product:  Component:  Status: Resolution: 
2. Version: Target Milestone: Severity: Priority: Hardware: OS: 

boxes are excessively wide for set #2, all boxes except OS are much wider than
needed for the choices in the selection lists.

the reason for wontfix of bug 654042 is a goal which seems reasonable ("The idea is that there is a "grid" on the page, and that the UI follows that grid") however
- afaict the selection boxes align only each other (set one and set two), with and nothing else in the query form 
- the results in BMO are IMO not reasonable ... we have boxes with tons of whitespace, i.e. wasted space, which translates into (avoidable) scrolling time.

Perhaps the size could be allowed to float, subject to a minimum width to help with aesthetics.

(In reply to comment #0)
> - afaict the selection boxes align only each other (set one and set two), with
> and nothing else in the query form

the width of all boxes in both sets are the same, so they do currently align with each other.

> Perhaps the size could be allowed to float, subject to a minimum width to help

i don't think there's a strong requirement to keep the width of selects in the first set to match the width in the second set.

i propose:

#detailed_information_section select {
    width: 14em;
}

Byron, thanks for looking at this.  What system and screen size was you screen shot taken?  (ludo also doesn't see wrapping on a Macbook pro 1440 by 900 screen)

my _work_ environment
win7
dell 2209wa 22" ultrasharp monitor
1680 x 1050 resolution
medium (125%) text size  (NOT default setting)
tabs on the left in firefox (NOT default setting)

updated info 
1. I discovered firefox was zoomed (NOT default setting), I think just one level of zoom.  
2. And I rediscovered that I don't use default text size because of old eyes :)
3. also, I use tabs on left, which makes great sense in a widescreen environment

screen shot attached with no zoom, and one zoom.  With no zoom the classification...product section  does not wrap but the detail section does wrap.  At one zoom level both wrap.  

conclusion: 14em in just the detailed section may be enough for this environment.  But I need to check the windows laptop screen at home (I don't recall the resolution setting).

(Looked at the screen shot) 
I think 14 is marginal and you could drop to 11em and do no damage because none of them need any appreciable width (most OSes should fit). Also, smaller value will fare much better in non-maximized windows. (might even be possible to go lower) 

For similar reasons, I'd drop to 14em or 15em (from 17em) in search_form.css - no boxes need appreciable width except for a few components.
